Morphemic: Nìl n-koti=ps-éhl-a pemkískahk [nòt ŏtúhk [n-tátat nehpa-h-á-c-il wolakù]CP]NP.
Translation: I am going to skin today that deer that my father killed yesterday.
Comment: Elicited examples in Passamaquoddy. The external head of a relative clause preceed the clause itself.

Translation: I am going to skin today that deer that my father killed yesterday.
Comment: Elicited examples in Passamaquoddy. Internal headded relative clauses.

Translation: The deer that my father killed is very big.
Comment: Elicited examples in Passamaquoddy. The distribution of proximate and obviative forms indicate that the head is clause-internal when it occupies the right periphery of the clause. In other words, apparent right-headed relative clauses are actually internally headed clauses.

Translation: The deer that my father killed is very big.
Comment: Elicited examples in Passamaquoddy. If the head could be external, then the example should have been acceptable, which is not the case here. Such unacceptability is predicted if a right-peripheral head occupies a position within the clause.

Translation: The deer that my father killed is very big.
Comment: Elicited examples in Passamaquoddy. This is a mixed type of structure for NP that include a relative clause. In this example, the head of the relative clause must be internal. The head is obviate while the n-tátat (my fater) is proximate. This proximate demonstrative appears in clause-initial position, but must be external to the relative clause itself.

Gloss: Piyel PERF-photograph-DIR-OBV man-OBV sell-3CONJINV FUT car
Translation: Piyel took a picture of the man who is going to sell him a car.
I saw those men in Calais.
The chair is at the rear of the church.
The seal swims along under the canoe.
The church and that house across the road need to be painted.
Comment: ksokayìw (across) takes áwti-k (road (LOC) as its complement. The modifier may preceed or follow the modified noun wíkŭwam (house).

Translation: The church and that house across the road need to be painted.
Comment: ksokayìw (across) takes áwti-k (road (LOC) as its complement. The modifier may preceed or follow the modified noun wíkŭwam (house).

Translation: The boy put the fork on the table by the window.
Comment: PP may serve as a modifier of a locative-marked noun. The modifying expression may either precede or follow the head of the NP.

Translation: The boy put the fork on the table by the window.
Comment: PP may serve as a modifier of a locative-marked noun. The modifying expression may either precede or follow the head of the NP.
